Kenward, Michael G. (1987).  A Method for Comparing Profiles of Repeated Measurements.  Applied Statistics, Vol. 36, pp. 296-308.

"Consider the following experiment on the control of intestinal paasites in cattle.  During the grazing season, from spring to autumn, cattle can ingest roundworm larvae which have developed from eggs previously deposited on the pasture in the faeces of infected cattle.  Once infected an animal is deprived of nutrients and its resistance to other disease is lowered, which in turn can greatly affect its growth.  The monitoring of the effects of a treatment for the disease requires observations to be made throughout the grazing season.  In an experiment to compare two methods, A and B say, for controlling the diseases, 60 animals were randomly assigned to treatment groups of size 30.  The animals were put out to pasture at the start of the grazing season, the members of each group receiving one of the two treatments.  The weight of each animal was then recorded 11 times to the nearest kilogram.  The first 10 measurements were made at two-weekly intervals and the final measurement was made after a one-week interval.  The esperimenter wishes to know if there is a difference in the between the groups in teh growth of the animals and, in particular, if such a difference exists, the time of measurement at which it first occurs.  "


Kenward (1987) cow data.  "Table 1.  Repeated measurements of weights (in kg) of calves from the trial on the control of intestinal parasites.  "  

id G  0   14  28  42  56  70  84  98 112 126 133
 1 A  233 224 245 258 271 287 287 287 290 293 297
 2 A  231 238 260 273 290 300 311 313 317 321 326
 3 A  232 237 245 265 285 298 304 319 317 334 329
 4 A  239 246 268 288 308 309 327 324 327 336 341
 5 A  215 216 239 264 282 299 307 321 328 332 337
 6 A  236 226 242 255 263 277 290 299 300 308 310
 7 A  219 229 246 265 279 292 299 299 298 300 290
